Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:The Physics of Signaling in Cell Membranes: Phosphoinositides and Small GTPases as a Paradigm.
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This CAREER award supports education, and theoretical and computational research on the molecular physics of signaling in cell membranes. The research involves theoretical and computational modeling at multiple scales. The fundamental underpinnings describe lipid-protein and protein-protein interactions with an ultimate view of understanding how these enter into the determinations of cell functions at the whole cell level.

The proposed work will consist of investigation of peptide-phospholipid interactions with atomic level resolution. The understanding at this level provides input for the description of phospholipids-protein and protein-protein interactions by coarse-grained models. In the most advanced stages, this work then takes up extending these coarse-grained models of proteins and lipids to investigate hydrodynamic interactions.

The award supports related educational activities that promote teaching, training and learning via integration of undergraduate and graduate students into the research process. The research will inform outreach activities supporting education in Iowa K-12 communities through workshops and other formal and informal interactions. Among these will be the involvement with local high schools to enhance science education with computational methods giving students capabilities of computer models of natural processes. By engaging graduate and undergraduate students in research, students at the university level, this work will also be providing education in cutting edge scientific based computer modeling capabilities and so enhance student education and professional skills.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
This CAREER award supports education, and theoretical and computational research on the molecular physics of the mechanisms employed by living cells to interact with the environment. The research is motivated to understand transport of materials and information, into and out of a cell, through complex processes occurring in the cell membrane. The research involves theoretical and computational modeling at multiple scales, taking studies of individual molecule that form the membranes and the proteins that carry out the signaling and then building up to more general understanding of how signaling and transport processes work with cell functions at the whole cell level.


The award supports related educational activities that promote teaching, training and learning via integration of undergraduate and graduate students into the research process. The research will inform outreach activities supporting education in Iowa K-12 communities through workshops and other formal and informal interactions. Among these will be the involvement with local high schools to enhance science education with computational methods giving students capabilities of computer models of natural processes. POR.DRECONTENT:
We investigated the mechanism by which certain proteins (GTPases, and more particularly, HRAS, which is involved in 30% of cancer tumors) carry their function and their interaction with lipids, more concretely, a family of lipids called Phosphoinositides. It is experimentally observed that the action of these proteins often occurs with a concurrent enhancement of calcium concentration, which in turn, is known to aggregate PIP2, and important member of the Phosphoinositide family.

The first project, carried by graduate student Sweta Vangaveti (Graduated October 2014), investigated the distribution of salt near a monolayer interface with different phospholipids. It was possible to characterize the salt distribution as a function of the lipid density (or molecular area), as summarized in the figure below:

The first case corresponds to lipids that are well separated in space,  and the ions next to them organize as a plasma. In the second case, which corresponds to the most common situation experimentally, the lipids are packed together, but leave room for ions to bind. Finally, if the lipids could be packed together more densely, they would behave as a uniform density where the actual lipid structure does not play any role. The calculation provides explicit predictions for binding constants, in excellent agreement with available experimental data.

Using these distributions, we have established that in the presence of calcium (and other divalent ions), an initially random distribution of lipids (such as the one in the figure right on the left) containing PIP2 and other lipids will gradually order  so that PIP2 are phase separated, as shown in the figure on the right. These results have been experimentally validated.

(An initial configuration of mixed phospholipids)                   (Final configuration in the presence of Calcium)

The second project, investigated by graduate student Abhijeet Kapoor (graduated November 2014), investigated how the G-proteins themselves carry their function. A common method to investigate protein motion is through all atom molecular dynamics, where each atom in the system is modeled. Although powerful, the method cannot reach the relevant time and spatial scales, so more coarse-grained models are required. We have developed a coarse-grained model that treats the solvent (water) implicitly, and models each aminoacid by four beads, leaving only five parameters to be determined, which is done by folding three given proteins to its native state.

As a test for the model, 18 proteins were successfully folded to their native states, and a comparison of the predicted (blue) to the actual (red) proteins are shown in the figure below.

The coarse-grained model can therefore be used to run molecular dynamics simulations that can reach very long time scales, and those predictions can then be verified by all atom molecular dynamics simulations. The problem that was addressed is then what are the conformational changes (allostery) involved when G-proteins perform these functions. Because there is ample experimental work, we focused our study on the Ras family of GTPases, and more concretely to H-RAS.

The action of H-RAS proceeds in four stages, and we have concentrated in the first stage, where the molecule GDP is ejected from HRAS. In real systems, this is mediated by an additional protein called GEF, but some general results can be obtained by analyzing the conformations of H-Ras with and without the GDP molecule. In particular, we have established that there are certain parts of the protein (Swich I, Switch II) that are coupled, and that certain residues (I21 and Y32) play a crucial role in inducing a transition that allows GD to escape.
